climbs.name: A Wizard Prang
climbs.fa: Jeff Everett, Duane Gillis, Tom O'Sullivan, Dec 1994

content.description:
Approach: Park just East of Stony Creek at the driveway to the ranger station. Walk East for a couple of hundred meters until an obvious creek is on your left. Head North directly up the creek bed for 15-20 minutes until going gets too difficult, gain the steep hillside and work your way out of the creek bed and continue up higher paralleling the creek. Drop back down into the creek where it makes sense (we got cliffed out and rapped a tree). 3 hours or so will get you to a split in the drainage with obvious rolling ice on the left, gear up here.

There are a couple of WI2 to WI3 steps of approach ice varying in length from 3 to 10 meters. Once past the prominent hanging tower turn left through trees into a side gully, up which you'll find the climb.

Climb: 50 meters of sustained vertical ice consisting of two 25 meter pillars.

Descend the same way you came.

Ice screws and cordage to rap on v threads.

climbs.name: Mudslide
climbs.fa: Brian Cork and Ryan Johnson, November 2002

content.description:
Approach: Park just East of Stony Creek at the driveway to the ranger station, walk East for a couple hundred meters until an obvious creek is on your left. Head North directly up the creek bed for 15-20 minutes until going gets too difficult, gain the steep hillside and work your way out of the creek bed and continue up higher paralleling it. Drop down back down into the creek where it makes sense (we got cliffed out and rapped a tree). 3 hours or so will get you to a split in the drainage with obvious rolling ice on the left. Gear up here.

Climbing: There are about 7 steps of approach ice varying in difficulty and length from 3 to 10 meters, WI2 to WI3. We only pitched out the longest WI3 section due to questionable ice.
After about 1.5 hours of approach ice you'll see the WI4+ pillar above and to the left. Climb 20 meters of technical and thin ice, mellowing out at the top of the cliffband. Traverse left to a sheltered belay with two smaller trees as an anchor. Rap off the trees and reverse the approach.

Ice screws and cordage to rap.
Holy Cross is just South of the seasonal closure gates on Highway 40. It contains a couple of very obscure ice climbs. A short drive from Calgary but a long slog up to the climbs.
